Guide to the Larry Rivers Papers
1952-2010
MSS 293
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Martin, 2013.

physdesc.extent: (100 record cartons, 51 document cases, 97 photo binders, 11 oversize boxes)

did.abstract: The Larry Rivers Papers include correspondence, manuscripts, source material, financial and administrative records, photographic material, project files, and audiovisual material related to the life of Larry Rivers, and to his work as an artist, poet, filmmaker and musician.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.
Audiovisual materials may not have been preserved and, therefore, may not be available to researchers.

Some materials have been restricted by Fales Library and the Larry Rivers Foundation due to potentially sensitive information contained in certain areas. Restricted materials are clearly indicated in the finding aid.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Larry Rivers Papers; MSS 293; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: The Larry Rivers Papers were purchased by the NYU's Fales Library & Special Collections from the Larry Rivers Foundation in 2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Larry Rivers was a painter, poet, jazz musician, videographer and filmmaker active in New York City and the Hamptons beginning in the 1940s and through the 1990s. Born in 1923 in the Bronx, Rivers initially pursued a career as a jazz saxophonist, and then became interested in painting, ultimately establishing himself as one of the most prolific American artists of the mid-20th century. He was resistant to the techniques and theory behind Abstract Expressionism; many of his works are considered progenitors of the Pop Art movement.

Following an honorable medical discharge from the U.S. Army Air Corps in 1943, Rivers studied music theory and composition at the Juilliard School. In the summers, Rivers toured with various jazz bands. During a residency in a music hall in Old Orchard Beach, Maine in 1945, Rivers met Jane Freilicher, whose husband Jack played in Rivers’s band. Freilicher introduced Rivers to painting, and his career ambitions began to shift. In 1947, having moved to Manhattan and become a regular on the downtown jazz and literary scene, Rivers enrolled in Hans Hofmann’s school of painting.

Rivers’s first solo exhibition of paintings occurred at the Jane Street Gallery in 1949. He spent most of the following year in Paris. In 1951 Rivers completed a B.A. in Art Education at New York University and began painting full time, under the representation of Tibor de Nagy Gallery. The first of several solo shows at the gallery occurred in 1951. John Bernard Myers, a partner at Tibor de Nagy, was an eager promoter of Rivers’s early work. Other early proponents included the poets John Ashbery, Kenneth Koch and Frank O’Hara, with whom Rivers would collaborate on many projects over the course of his career. In 1953 Rivers relocated to Southampton, Long Island, along with his sons Joseph and Steven and his mother in-law “Berdie” Burger.

1953 proved a turning point in Rivers’s career with the completion and exhibition of his epic painting, Washington Crossing the Delaware. With its muddy color palate, figurative technique and historical subject matter, the painting was iconoclastic alongside most major contemporary artworks, which adhered stringently to the theories and representational techniques of Abstract Expressionism. The painting was purchased by the Museum of Modern Art in 1955.

In the early 1950s Rivers began experimenting with other art forms, including sculpture and set design. He first worked with plaster, then wire sculpture, and his first sculpture exhibition opened in 1954. He contributed sets to numerous theater and opera productions, beginning with Frank O’Hara’s “Try! Try!” in 1952, as well as later works by LeRoi Jones, Kenward Elmslie, Kenneth Koch, and an adaptation of Stravinsky’s Oedipus Rex directed by Lukas Foss.

In 1961 Rivers lived in Paris with his fiancée, Clarice Price. Their studio was adjacent to that of artists Niki de Saint-Phalle and Jean Tinguely. The neighbors became fast friends and collaborated on numerous works, beginning with Rivers and Tinguely’s The Friendship of America and France. Rivers completed several major works while in Paris, including the French Vocabulary Lessons series and Proto-Pop works such as the Lucky Strike and French Money series, which were exhibited at the Galerie Rive Droite.

Rivers completed another monumental work, History of the Russian Revolution: From Marx to Maykovsky, a mixed media construction of several paintings and sculptures measuring over 30 feet long and 14 feet high, in 1965. It debuted at the final stop of Rivers’s first touring retrospective exhibition, at the Jewish Museum in New York.
In 1966, Rivers was devastated by the sudden tragic death at age 40 of Frank O’Hara, a former lover, intimate friend and collaborator, and a major muse for Rivers.

The following year, Rivers joined film director Pierre Gaisseau to produce a television documentary in Central Africa. Filming was completed over two trips; in Benin in 1968 Rivers and Gaisseau were arrested as suspected Western mercenaries, and nearly executed. The film, Africa & I, provided Rivers with a chance to explore a lifelong fascination with Africa, and strengthened his interest in moving image work.

Beginning in 1969 Rivers’s paintings underwent a stylistic shift as he began working with spray cans and airbrushing, as well as constructing 3-dimensional surfaces for canvases using layered foam board. During the same period Rivers began working with videotape. He produced several ½” open reel video works in the 1970s, many documentary in nature, often in collaboration with his son Steven, and/or video artists Michel Auder and Diana Molinari. In 1976, Larry and Steven Rivers traveled to the Soviet Union as a guest of the Union of Soviet Artists. They brought a video camera and captured footage of their travels and visits to artists’ studios.

Rivers worked on several thematic series of works throughout the 1980s and 90s, including The Continuing Interest in Abstract Art, History of Matzah (The Story of the Jews), Make Believe Ballroom, Art and the Artist, and The History of Hollywood. In 1992 What Did I Do? The Unauthorized Autobiography, written with Arnold Weinstein, was published. Rivers continued to create and show work, dividing his time between his loft building on East 14th Street in New York, his house in Southampton, and his studio in Zihuatanejo, Mexico, until his death in 2002.
"Chronology." Larry Rivers Foundation. Web. Accessed 19 May 2014. http://larryriversfoundation.org/chronology.html.
Rivers, Larry, with Arnold Weinstein. What Did I Do? The Unauthorized Autobiography. New York: Harper Collins, 1992.
For comprehensive biographical information and chronology, visit the Larry Rivers Foundation at: http://www.larryriversfoundation.org.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
The Larry Rivers Papers include correspondence, manuscripts, ephemera, photographic material, business and administrative records, source material, film, video recordings, audio Recordings, sheet music, legal and financial records. Materials in the archive document Rivers’ life and career as a painter, poet, videographer, filmmaker, and musician. The collection is arranged into 17 series:
Series I: Correspondence primarily contains personal correspondence. As many of Rivers’ personal friends were also associates and collaborators, the content of this series often straddles the line between the personal and the professional.
Series II: Manuscripts & Writings contains written works by Rivers as well as manuscripts and drafts of works by other artists, including poems, plays, films, interviews, lectures, papers, and Rivers’ autobiography.
Series III: Photographic Material contains photographic prints, slides, contact sheets and negatives. In addition to the collection of photographic prints documenting Rivers’ life and career, this series contains several inventory binders and source material.
Series IV: Project Files contains archival materials related to the artistic career of Larry Rivers. These include business correspondence, exhibition files, preparatory notes, ephemera and work documentation.
Series V: Source Material contains source files for Rivers’ artworks, primarily photographic material.
Series VI: Clippings contains articles clipped from newspapers, magazines and other published materials, some to be used as research material, others for documentation purposes.
Series VII: Music contains materials related to Rivers’ musical career, including sheet music, correspondence and ephemera related to different bands and musical performances.
Series VIII: Administrative Files contains materials related to the operations of Larry Rivers’ Studio. These include memoranda, meeting minutes, documentation of conservation work and artwork photography, and collections of exhibition documentation for both Larry Rivers and other artists.
Series IX: Financial Records contains financial records related to Larry Rivers’ personal and artistic career. This series is restricted; permission must be obtained from a Fales archivist for access to these materials.
Series X: Legal Records contains legal documents, including those related to specific legal cases, law research, and parking/traffic violations.
Series XI: Medical Records contains medical records. This series is restricted.
Series XII: Real Estate contains records related to properties owned by Larry Rivers. These include homes in Southampton and Zihuatanejo, Mexico, as well as the famous loft at 404 East 14th Street.
Series XIII: Personal Files contains materials unrelated to Larry Rivers’ artistic or musical career. These include files related to Rivers’ family and various community/outreach organizations.
Series XIV: Audio contains audio cassettes and reels.
Series XV: Film contains film reels, primarily 16mm acetate film.
Series XVI: Video contains ½” open reel, ¾” Umatic, VHS, and Betamax video.
Series XVII: Data Storage comprises seven 3 ½” floppy disks containing source material.
Series XVIII: Commercial Media Collection comprises Rivers’ collection of vinyl records, audiocassettes, CDs and DVDs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Larry Rivers Papers are arranged primarily at the folder level, divided into series based on their original order and characteristic affinities which emerged during processing. Folder titles are based on original labeling. At times titles were marginally altered for the sake of uniformity. Any titles inferred by the archivist are enclosed in square brackets; these were coined using the example of other similar files in the archives.
Oversize materials and objects were removed from their original locations to allow for adequate housing, and can be found in the oversize series in the finding aid.

The collection is arranged into 17 series:
Series I: Correspondence
Series II: Manuscripts & Writings
Series III: Photographic Material
Series IV: Project Files
Series V: Source Material
Series VII: Music
Series VIII: Administrative Files
Series IX: Financial Records
Series X: Legal Records
Series XI: Medical Records
Series XII: Real Estate
Series XIII: Personal Files
Series XIV: Sound recordings
Series XV: Film
Series XVI: Video recordings
Series XVII: Data Storage
Series XVIII: Commercial Media Collection

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series I: Correspondence contains Larry Rivers's personal correspondence. It has been separated into four subseries: personal correspondence from named correspondents, correspondence from unknown senders, fan mail, and non-unique and informal correspondence. Each subseries is described in greater detail below.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries A features personal correspondence from known and identified senders -- or recipients, as pertaining to drafts of letters written by Rivers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged alphabetically by surname. In cases where the correspondent's first name is given but surname is not known, the first name is used as identifier. Within each folder, materials are arranged chronologically. Important clarifying information about specific items may be included below in notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries C contains materials regarded loosely as "fan mail." These include but are not limited to autograph requests, casual inquiries about Rivers's work, and responses to public appearances. A number of items in this subseries pertain specifically to Rivers's appearance on "The $64,000 Challenge" (1957) and his publication of an article in Seventeen Magazine (1964).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series IV: Project Files contains documents related directly to the artistic career of Larry Rivers. These have been arranged into three subseries, based upon their original arrangement and notation schemes of Rivers and his studio.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The three subseries were chosen based upon the original notations of Rivers and his studio. Three separate filing strategies emerged during the course of processing the collection; the subseries correspond with these rubricks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries A contains correspondence and records related to sales, loans and exhibitions of Rivers' artworks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The title "artwork tracking" was chosen based on the term's frequent recurrence on original boxes and folders. Materials are arranged alphabetically by folder title; within each folder, materials are in their original order. Folders with identical titles are arranged by date. Any titles inferred by the archivist are enclosed in square brackets.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: NOTE: Contains oversized blueprints, which require extra table space for viewing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series V: Source Material contains source files for Larry Rivers' work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is split into two subseries. The first comprises the source file, as maintained by Rivers and his studio. The second comprises source files found outside of the numbered source file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Subseries A comprises the source file maintained by Larry Rivers and his studio.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are in their original order; each numbered source file comprised a large packet or hanging file folder containing several more specific folders. Subjects contained in each numbered source file are listed in expository notes. Original folder labels have been retained in each folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series VIII: Administrative Files contains materials related to the operations of Larry Rivers’ Studio. These include memoranda, meeting minutes, documentation of conservation work and artwork photography, and collections of exhibition documentation for both Larry Rivers and other artists.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged alphabetically by folder title. Items within each folder are in their original order. Any titles inferred by the archivist are enclosed in square brackets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series XII: Real Estate contains records related to properties owned by Larry Rivers. These include homes in Southampton and Zihuatanejo, Mexico, as well as the famous loft at 404 East 14th Street.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged alphabetically by folder title. Items within each folder are in their original order. Any titles inferred by the archivist are enclosed in square brackets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged alphabetically by folder title. Items within each folder are in their original order. Any titles inferred by the archivist are enclosed in square brackets.

did.unittitle: National Society of Literature and the Arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series XIV: Audio contains audio cassettes and reels.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Audio items were given unique identification numbers in their original order. Unique titles are based upon annotations on original items and their containers. Alternate titles are offered where multiple titles were implied by container annotations, or in the case of uniform titles for series of items.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Preservation work has not been performed on these items, and therefore they may not be available for access. Please contact the Fales for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series XVI: Video contains ½” open reel, ¾” Umatic, VHS, and Betamax video.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Video items were given unique identification numbers in their original order. Unique titles are based upon annotations on original items and their containers. Alternate titles are offered where multiple titles were implied by container annotations, or in the case of uniform titles for series of items.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Availability of access copies is indicated in each item description. Please contact the Fales for more information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: While in California, Rivers taught a course at University of California, Santa Barbara, and gathered material for use in the operatic adaptation of Kenneth Koch's poem, "The Artist". This tape primarily contains home movie-style footage taken around the western United States.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers visits a California park at which rabies shots are being administered to local dogs by Animal Control, and tapes a professional tree cutter at work. The final 10 minutes contain home movie-style footage of Rivers with his children in their Long Island home.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage shot in Paris, includes sculptures by Jean Tinguely and Niki de Saint-Phalle in a park, and street scenes.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers takes his camera on the flight from New York to Sotckholm for the Stockholm Museum of Modern Art Group Show of American Artists. The flight is full of American Artists whose work featured in the show. Features footage on the plane, at an airport bar, and in a private first class cabin on the airplane.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

did.unittitle: End of Stockholm Opening, Visit to Palace

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Larry Rivers interviewing guests at the opening of a group show at Swedish Museum of Modern Art; a tour of the Stockholm Royal Palace.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

did.unittitle: Swedish Museum - American Works in Moderna Museet

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Larry Rivers giving a tour of the Stockholm Museum of Modern Art Group Show opening, discussing various works, interviewing visitors.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: A lower-quality, shortened duplicate of "Swedish Museum - American Collection" (293.0005_a).

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In Washington, D.C., Rivers and his son Steven join other artists as they march, demostrate and deliver a signed petition against the Vietnam war. After a demonstration and march to Congress, various Congresspeople speak out their opposition to the war.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In Washington, D.C., Rivers and his son Steven join other artists as they march, demostrate and deliver a signed petition against the Vietnam war. After a demonstration and march to Congress, various Congresspeople speak out their opposition to the war.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: DVD access copy available by appointment.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers follows a group of artists and activists after they deliver to Congress a signed petition against the Vietnam war. The protestors crowd the Capitol to hear responses from other government officials. A number of peaceful protestors are arrested for refusing to leave the Capitol.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: The wedding of Rivers's cousin, in a park in Peekskill, NY. Rivers tapes the ceremony and talks to guests at the reception.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

did.unittitle: Peekskill Wedding 2 and Puerto Rican Fiesta (13th Street)

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: The conclusion of the wedding footage, followed by footage of a Father's Day street party in the East Village.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In the first 9 minutes, Michel Auder and Rivers take a fanboat tour of the Everglades; the remainder of the tape contains a tour of the Royal Palm Beach lion safari park. Everglades footage is in color; safari footage is in black & white.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Michel Auder and Rivers visit Disney World, exploring the grounds and interviewing staff, performers and guests.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

did.unittitle: Florida Seminole Village Snakes and Crocodiles

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In Florida, Rivers and Michel Auder visit a historic Seminole village, which houses snakes, crocodiles and other wildlife. Handlers perform demonstrations in the snake pit and the alligator habitat.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Home movie-style footage from a trip to Sarasota, Florida, in advance of a Rivers print show at a gallery there. Rivers talks to vacationers and locals visits with a local environmental preservation group, and visits an artist's studio.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers and Michel Auder drive from Sarasota to Miami, Florida. Along the way they stop to interview locals in various towns; Rivers receives a speeding ticket on the Florida turnpike. In Miami, they visit the Hafts on the north bay.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers visits Port au Prince, Haiti. "Home video" style footage includes an open air marketplace, various street scenes, and the pool at a luxury hotel.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, Rivers and Michel Auder explore the town square and interviews locals through an interpreter. Outside the city, they visit a sugar cane plantation and a beach, interviewing whomever they meet.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: "Home movie" style footage of the end of Rivers's trip to Port au Prince, Haiti. Rivers films a band performing for new arrivals at the airport.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In Port au Prince, Haiti, Rivers and Diana Molinari visit an art gallery and market, explore the town, and watch a voodoo ceremony.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage of the Haitian Voodoo ceremony, continued from the end of 293.0021.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: In Haiti, Rivers interviews a visiting tourist and films a performing contortionist.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage from Rivers's trip to Africa; plane arriving in Ndutu; a tour of the living quarters; animals in the wild; animal carcasses and skulls, feeding hyenas and vultures.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Wildlife in Ndutu; driving through the wilds of Ndutu, stopping to look at wildlife, animal carcasses, trees etc.; luring hyenas to a wildebeest carcass.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Hyenas feeding on a wildebeest carcass in Ndutu.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Hyenas feeding on a carcass in Ndutu; children and townspeople, a driving tour of a nearby city.

scopecontent.head: Original Annotations:
scopecontent.p: "Jackals and carcass, Larry and Peter, Head of wildebeest, Nairobi in car".

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Townspeople and children in Nairobi; a driving tour of the town of Nairobi.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage from inside an airplane as it takes off and flies to Manyara; Larry Rivers, filming himself in a mirror while experimenting with a new camera and asking the viewer's forgiveness for his mistakes; landing in Manyara and exploring the area.

scopecontent.head: Original Annotations:
scopecontent.p: "Manyara take off, flight landing, Larry explaining hotel, road, entrance, etc".

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: On safari in Manyara, footage of wildlife and footage taken from the moving vehicle; footage of tourists and camp inhabitants.

scopecontent.head: Original Annotations:
scopecontent.p: "In Manyara, baboons, safari cars, elephants, Ian's camp, Aureo's interview".

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Safari footage, shot from inside and outside the vehicle; swimming at a waterfall in Manyara.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Safari footage; flying over the coast; measuring tree growth.

scopecontent.head: Original Annotations:
scopecontent.p: "Manyara Zeebs, Grafs, Elys, Flying, Huts, Ian measuring trees".

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Measuring tree growth in the bush; safari wildlife; herds of animals filmed from a low-flying plane.

scopecontent.head: Original Annotations:
scopecontent.p: "Manyara, measuring, portrait Mohoja, Lions in tree, farewell, flying".

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers testing the camera, filming himself in a mirror; a marching drum procession through city streets; Rivers introducing the video as a whole; animals on Peter Beard's farm; interview with the son of a prominent tribal chief, with Peter Beard as translator; shots of the city from a hotel room.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Deplaning in Ndutu; unloading and touring the Ndutu campsite; some Safari footage, finding a zebra skeleton.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Ndutu safari footage, some shot from a moving vehicle; wildebeest carcasses, lions.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers interviewing other American tourists in Ndutu; meeting two Masai boys before departing; test shots from hotel room in Nairobi.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Safari in Ndutu; Rivers teaching Barbara Allen how to use his video camera.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Practice edits from Rivers's travels in Africa with Peter Beard.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage of animals; interviews with the Rivers and the other guests of Peter Beard, on his birthday.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: A press conference in New York City for Peter Beard's upcoming book. Attendees chatting in advance of the coference, and the beginning of the conference itself.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Peter Beard speaking at his book-release press conference, about conservation and loss of natural habitat and indigenous land in Africa, and the past and future of the African people.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: At an exhibition opening for Peter Beard's photographs, Rivers chats with attendees about the works.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers and his son Steven visit artists' studios, discussing the artists' works, the Soviet Union and showing in America, and take a driving tour of the city, in Leningrad.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers and his son Steven tour mausoleums and various locations in Samarkand; Rivers takes test shots out of his hotel room; footage of a cotton mill in Bukhara.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage of Leningrad, shot by Rivers and his son Steven. Steven speaks to people on the streets of Leningrad, including some American tourists. Exploring various parts and landmarks of Leningrad.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Footage of Moscow, shot by Rivers and his son Steven. Shots of and from the Hotel Ukraine, Moscow. Steven interviews people on the streets of Moscow, including tourists and locals. Footage in front of the Kremlin, with narration from an English speaking guide. Exploring various areas and landmarks around Moscow. More footage from Leningrad - similar content to that of 293.0046_a.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers discusses his work and the relationship of the United States with Russia and China. Also discusses the arts environment in the Soviet Union at the time, and the effects his visit has had upon his views of the Soviet Union and potential influences upon future work.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Visit to a Russian artist's studio. Rivers views artworks in the studio, discussing them, through a translator, with the artist and a few others. They then sit and discuss the American arts scene and abstract expressionism.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Rivers visits the Russian Museum, viewing works with an English-speaking guide. Some footage of the hotel room in Leningrad in which Rivers and his son Steven are staying. Driving through Leningrad.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: Tape opens with 4 minutes of footage from Alfred Hitchcock's "The Birds", then cuts to Rivers's work about Abbie Hoffman's vasectomy. This is the first part of the work, featuring Hoffman introducing himself and beginning the discussion with Rivers about his plan to get a vasectomy and the general subject of contraception. Rivers attends a Kiwanis Club meeting to discuss Hoffman's story with the members and show them footage of the vasectomy operation.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Man in a cape walking by some water and picking flowers; feeds some geese. Two women driving in a car pick up this man - the village idiot. They take him home and listen to the Rolling Stones. They put some poison in a drink they are planning to give him. He makes-out with one of the women and the other one kills him with a blow to the head. Audio cuts out sometimes.
Outside scenes on the street. The idiot is alive again.

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: A Camera Three documentary on Tatyana Grosman and her print shop, Universal Limited Art Editions. "The Donkey and the Darling," by Rivers and Terry Southern, is featured. Rivers and Southern discuss the work, and Rivers demonstrates his drawing technique. Other works by Jasper Johns, Rivers, Robert Motherwell, James Rosenquist and others are shown.
